repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: json_encode() uses a C template-based encoder that mishandles
certain invalid UTF-8 sequences (e.g. overlong encodings like \xc0\x81).

Solution: Replace the encoder path with lua_cjson (vim.json.encode).
Add a new typval_encode template (json_lua) in converter.c that performs
JSON validation (float, string, key, recursion checks) while pushing
values onto the Lua stack, then let lua_cjson serialize to JSON.

Fix #28683

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -707,7 +707,7 @@ endfunc
 func Test_blob_json_encode()
   let lines =<< trim END
       #" call assert_equal('[222,173,190,239]', json_encode(0zDEADBEEF))

comment_regular_data.body:
> some error messages of the test case may require more detailed object handling?

json_encode/json_decode have very detailed error messages, thanks to ZyX's work. And those messages are more granular than Vim's, I believe. But we would likely need to make this tradeoff, if we're going to use cjson instead.

>  And those messages are more granular than Vim's, I believe.
 
that's true.  some converted formats may also need to be processed like space padding

```
Passed in:
(string) '{"d":[]}'
Expected:
(string) '{"d": []}'
```

> some converted formats may also need to be processed

Not sure what you mean, but just to be clear: unless proven otherwise, I think we should just use whatever messages come from cjson. This means tests will need to be updated. We shouldn't try to "convert" the cjson messages to match the old json_encode/json_decode messages. Unless that causes a big problem that I didn't foresee.
cjson return `'{"d":[]}'`  and expecte is `'{"d": []}'`  a space after colon
That is not a meaningful difference worth _any_ code to "fix"; just adapt the "expected" test to the new output.
ok I just wanted to confirm if this expected format is intentional to avoid breaking some behavior before i edit some expecteds
Is this WIP? Please mark as Draft if so. I would expect a lot of code to be deleted (that is the purpose of doing this)

To preserve `_TYPE/_VAL` backward compat, I had to add a full `typval_encode` template instance in converter.c . The reason is `_TYPE` identification relies on C pointer comparison 
`type_di->vval.v_list == eval_msgpack_type_lists[kMPString]` â€” that identity is lost after `vim_to_object`, so `NLUA_EXEC_STATIC`  can't work. The template was the only way to resolve `_TYPE/_VAL` on the C side while pushing to Lua stack. Also needed a `__tojson` userdata hack for uint64 values that overflow lua doubles...Perhaps there's a better way that idk ? ðŸ¤”

If we're okay with dropping `_TYPE/_VAL` support in `json_encode`, the whole thing becomes just an NLUA_EXEC_STATIC call. this would be simpler ...

> If we're okay with dropping `_TYPE/_VAL` support in `json_encode`, the whole thing becomes just an NLUA_EXEC_STATIC call

I think we should drop that feature. What do others think?

labels.name: refactor

title: refactor(eval): use vim.json inside f_json_encode
